Comment: I opt for the Giuoco Piano, meaning "Quiet Game" in Italian. In some countries this is known as the Italian Game.
and he responds with the main line

I play this rather than try for an immediate advantage with d4. After 5. d4 exd4 6. cxd4 Black can play Bb4+ with a reasonable game. So instead I play a version of the Giuoco Pianissimo, "Very quiet Game", going for a slow build-up, castling first and maybe playing d4 when I am better develped. Black has played well so far.
He opens a diagonal for his bishop.

I gain space on the queen side. The position is virtually level. Both a5 and a6 are perfectly playable for black. Bxc4 may be OK too. Instead he seems to miss my threat, and also makes another mistake, that of moving a piece twice in the opening, for no good reason.
This makes no sense. If he wanted to put his bishop on this square why not do so on move 7?
